area_name: Camp Bird Mine Rd/Mountain Rescue Cache Crag

content.description:
Needful Things follows four left-angling bolts between

Natural Selection

and

Falling Apart at the Seams

. At the fourth bolt, trend up and left into

Natural Selection

. The upper section is protected by some tricky wires and small to medium cams.

climbs.name: Natural Selection
climbs.fa: Jason Nelson, Logan Tyler, Justin Putnam

content.description:
We tried to keep this route as "trad" as possible and at the time the boys were inspired by the film

"Hard Grit"

, but we weren't quite willing to go that far with our style of ascent.  The bolts are spaced, but if I remember correctly, Chris Parker blew the second clip and still didn't hit the ground, so I guess it doesn't get an "R" rating.  Anyway, the climbing if fun, the rock quality is great. It's a spicy, tricky lead though, so you may want to check it out on toprope first (which is easily accomplished).
content.location:
This is located just right of the prominent

Roadside Attraction

crack.  3 bolts lead to a seam that protects with gear.

content.description:
Kids in the Candy Store shares the same start as

Instant Crusher

. Clip the first bolt, then angle right to two more bolts. The route stays left of the crack system. Climb the face left of the crack. The holds are mainly posiitive, although they are tricky to find.
content.protection: 3 bolts, then you need gear to #1 (mainly micro gear), then you get cold shuts for anchors.
content.location: The route is located on the east face of Roadside Attraction. It can be seen from the overlook above.

content.description: There's nothing bad about this climb. It's the obvious north-facing crack that fires up the rhodenite wall. Awesome.
content.protection: Good protection all the way with small to medium gear. Top out, you'll find some anchors.

climbs.name: Instant Crusher aka The Mississippi Two-Step

content.description:
Start off the ground with some powerful cruxy moves on well protected climbing. The climb is fairly sustained thereafter, but with good rests, on nice horizontal holds.

This route follows high quality, natural line trending slightly left. This is a great climb for those wanting to push their skills to the next level.

The route was established during a guide's course and named after a Jeeping accident caused by spontaneous rock fall near the Skylight ice climbing area.
content.protection: Bolts, 2 bolt anchor. You can walk off the back / TR easily.
content.location: Drive to the Ice Park (Camp Bird Mine Rd) and park at the first major switchback past the Mountain Rescue Cache on the right and the CDOT building on the left. Follow the chain link fence to the right of the powder house to the south (uphill) and follow a trail to the left where the fence ends to a rhodenite outcrop about 20m from the fence. The climb faces north and begins near a low-angled slab to the left of the climb.

content.description: This is a super amazing contribution to a classic Ouray crag! It was first done by local strongman, Jason Nelson. Follow an incipient seam, protected by small gear, to two bolts (the crux) followed by a few more gear placements.
content.location: F.A.A.T.S. is located on the far right side of the Roadside Crag. The beginning of the route is best identified by a gumbie placed copperhead, 4 feet off the ground. The thin seam will be obvious.

pathTokens: Camp Bird Mine Rd/Mountain Rescue Cache Crag
